entry.title: Sales Order Pricing Trigger Based on Custom Field
entry.content:
This blog shows how the Sales Order pricing can be triggered when a custom field is populated or updated in a Sales Order.

Background

Sales Orders are created in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system via the Manage Sales Order app or can be created via the API. When these sales orders are created or updated, the pricing is triggered only when certain standard fields such as item category, plant, sold-to or ship-to party is entered or updated. A custom field at the Sales Order header or item level won’t automatically trigger pricing.

The use case here is that discount code/promotion code is captured as a custom field, which can be at the header or item level dependent upon the business requirement. The discount code corresponds to a percentage, which is reflected as percentage discount in the pricing condition.

When a Sales Order is manually created and the discount code (custom field) is entered after the initial pricing has already occurred, then repricing is executed only after manually clicking update pricing at the header or item level. Also, when the sales order is created via the API, the discount code (custom field) is not taken into account in the calculation of pricing condition.

The blog describes how extensibility can be used for automatic repricing of sales orders, created via the API or via the manage sales order app in the system, when custom field (discount code/ promotion code) is populated with a specific value.

Solution using Extensibility

The solution leverages business object I_SALESORDERTP, which provides an update prices option and can be used to update the pricing condition record when discount code is populated. This is achieved by using the object to call the update pricing function immediately after the API creates the sales order or by exposing an API that automatically triggers repricing upon the creation when the discount code field is populated.

SAP BTP Event Mesh is used to generate the event and Event Consumption Model handles the event processing in the corresponding class.

Following extensibility objects are used in the solution:

1. Custom Field

Dependent upon the business requirement, whether discount code is captured at the line item or header level, custom field is created at the Sales Order Header or Sales Order Item level

a. Custom Field at Sales Order Item level

Create a custom field with business context: Sales: Sales Document Item.

Extend the custom field to the APIs:

  • Sales Order (A2X, OData V4)
  • I_SalesOrderItemTP

b. Custom Field at Sales Order Header level

Create a custom field with business context: Sales: Sales Document

Extend the custom field to the APIs:

  • Sales Order (A2X, OData V4)
  • I_SalesOrderTP

2. ABAP Class

ABAP Class is created via Developer’s extensibility. This would be singleton buffer class used to temporarily store and retrieve data related to Sales Order Header and Item values.

First, ABAP Package is created

In this step, one creates a class by providing name and description

3. Custom Business Object

Custom Business Object is used to store discount code/ promotion code and corresponding discount percentage and is created via Custom Business Objects app

In the Custom Business Objects app, create a new object, ensuring features shown below are selected.

In the Fields tab add fields relevant to the discount code e.g. discount code/description, Discount Percentage, Valid From/To date etc.

After publishing the custom business object, click Maintain Catalogs.

Add the Business Catalog „Extensibility – Custom Business Objects“ and publish it.

In the generated UI corresponding to the custom business object, maintain the relevant discount codes/ promotion codes as defined in the custom business object.

4. BADI Implementation

To manage pricing elements for Sales Order following Business Add-Ins must be implemented via Custom Logic app.

a. BADI: SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM

This BADI save values for custom fields

b. BADI:  PRCG_DOC_ITEM_CONDITION_AMOUNT

This BADI is used to update value for Item Pricing Element in the Sales Order.

In this example standard discount pricing condition „DRG1“  is updated with the discount percentage corresponding to the discount/promotion code.

Outcome:

As a result of above extensibility solution, whenever the sales order header or item custom field (discount code / promotion code) contains or is updated with valid value, the pricing is triggered reflecting discount percentage corresponding to the discount/ promotion code in the condition type DRG1.

In the below example Sales Order OData V4 API contains valid discount/promotion code (e.g. "SUMMER2025") at the item level.

The promotion code shows in Sales Order item level

The pricing condition „DRG1“ is updated with the discount percentage corresponding to the promotion code „SUMMER2025“.

Summary:

This blog showed how key user and developer extensibility objects can be used to automatically trigger pricing in Sales Order based on the custom fields.

 

Disclaimer: 

The sample code in the blog is provided as a reference implementation to demonstrate the concept. It may not cover all edge cases and should be customized, optimized and validated according to your business requirements and system design.

 

Co-authored with: @DennisLeslie

In my repository, UI.xxxHidden annotations work as expected.

entry.title: 6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discovery-First Approach
entry.content:
As Technical Architect we are supposed to pull out the rabbit from the hat, everytime you are in a conversation of AI with respect to SAP IT Estate. Am sharing my approach with the community on how we are exploring this 'Discovery' phase without falling into the trap of 'how will I implement it'.

With the evolution of SAP S/4HANA and the increasing maturity of SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), Artificial Intelligence is no longer an external add-on to SAP landscapes. SAP has embedded AI capabilities directly into its core through services such as SAP AI Core, AI Launchpad, Joule, embedded machine learning in S/4HANA, and intelligent process automation on BTP. As a result, organizations are no longer asking whether AI is relevant to SAP, but where and how it can deliver measurable value.

Despite this progress, many AI initiatives in SAP environments struggle to move beyond pilots. A common root cause is the absence of a structured AI discovery phase that is aligned with SAP business processes, data structures, and enterprise operating models. Before leveraging SAP’s built-in AI capabilities or extending them through BTP, organizations must first identify the 'right' AI use cases.

This article outlines a six-step AI assessment approach I use to focused exclusively on discovery, designed to help SAP consultants and system integrators systematically identify and prioritize AI use cases in S/4HANA-centric landscapes. The approach is technology-aware but implementation-agnostic, ensuring that discovery outcomes remain valid regardless of deployment choices.

Step 1: Frame the AI Assessment Scope in an S/4HANA Landscape

The foundation of an effective AI assessment is a clearly defined scope. In SAP environments, this typically includes S/4HANA application areas such as Finance, Supply Chain, Manufacturing, Sales, Asset Management, and Human Resources, along with adjacent systems integrated via SAP BTP.

At this stage, the objective is not to assess SAP AI Core configurations or BTP services, but to establish 'where' AI exploration is relevant. Business capability maps, value streams, or process hierarchies are particularly effective inputs, as they provide a stable abstraction independent of system customizations.

Equally important is explicitly positioning the assessment as discovery-only. No architectural decisions, tool comparisons, or implementation commitments should be made. This constraint preserves neutrality and ensures that use cases are driven by business need rather than platform bias.

The cheat an architect can use here is to think of all possibilities and not to get into the trap of thinking how one will implement to solution.

Step 2: Map Business Capabilities to S/4HANA Processes

AI use cases in SAP emerge at the intersection of business capabilities and S/4HANA processes. Therefore, the next step is to map enterprise capabilities—such as Forecast-to-Stock or Hire-to-Retire—to the underlying S/4HANA processes and transactional flows that realize them.

This mapping shifts the discussion away from modules and transactions toward business outcomes. It also highlights areas where standard S/4HANA processes are supplemented by manual activities, spreadsheets, or external decision-making—common indicators of AI opportunity.

For system integrators, this step is particularly valuable, as it anchors AI discovery in SAP-standard process models while still accommodating client-specific variations.

The cheat an architect can use here is to hghlight data-heavy or repetitive processes and identify high touchpoint sub processes.

Step 3: Identify AI Opportunities Using SAP-Relevant Heuristics

With process mapping in place, AI discovery heuristics are applied to identify candidate use cases. In S/4HANA landscapes, these heuristics align closely with scenarios already supported or extensible through SAP AI services.

Processes characterized by high manual effort, frequent exceptions, or repetitive validations often indicate opportunities for intelligent automation. Decision-intensive processes, such as demand planning, cash forecasting, or risk assessment, suggest predictive or optimization use cases. Classification-heavy activities—including document processing, master data enrichment, and service ticket categorization—are well suited for machine learning approaches. Conversational scenarios emerge where users require natural-language access to SAP data or procedural knowledge.

The cheat an architect can use here is to look into the historical data, system logs, process mining data, time and motions study data to form a baseline. Applying these ideas consistently ensures that AI use cases are identified systematically rather than opportunistically.

Step 4: Score Opportunities - Qualitatively Assess Value, Feasibility, and Adoption Readiness

Discovery requires prioritization, but prioritization during this phase should remain lightweight and qualitative. Each identified AI use case is assessed across three dimensions.

Business value reflects the potential impact on efficiency, cost, compliance, or decision quality. Feasibility considers data availability within S/4HANA, integration complexity, and alignment with existing automation or BTP usage. Adoption readiness evaluates organizational factors such as user acceptance, process ownership, and change impact.

The architect needs to check the technology readiness only at this stage. Identify the technology stack, check availability, and what is needed to be procured. 

The cheat for an architect here is that this assessment is comparative rather than absolute. The goal is not to build a business case, but to distinguish high-potential use cases from those that are premature or misaligned.

 Step 5: Build an AI Impact Heatmap for SAP Processes

The outputs of the assessment are consolidated into an AI impact heatmap, which serves as the primary deliverable of the discovery phase. The heatmap visualizes AI use cases across SAP processes against dimensions such as value and feasibility.

Use cases positioned in the high-value, high-feasibility quadrant typically represent strong candidates for subsequent proof-of-concept initiatives using SAP AI Core or BTP services. High-value but lower-feasibility cases are documented as strategic backlog items, often dependent on data quality or process standardization improvements. Low-impact cases are consciously deprioritized.

For SAP programs, the heatmap provides a shared language between business stakeholders, functional consultants, and technical architects.

The cheat an architect can use here is to identify high-value use cases with feasible technology, data & integration.

Step 6: Select Discovery Candidates

The final step of discovery is to consolidate findings into a short list of prioritized AI use cases, usually limited to three to five candidates. These use cases should demonstrate clear business relevance, alignment with S/4HANA processes, and reasonable feasibility within the current SAP landscape.

Common examples identified during SAP AI discovery include intelligent invoice processing, predictive MRP, conversational assistants for SAP user support, and automated sales order validation. However, the true value of discovery lies in identifying 'context-specific' opportunities rather than replicating generic patterns.

At this point, the AI assessment concludes. Any further activities—such as solution architecture, SAP AI Core enablement, or BTP service selection—belong to subsequent phases and should be initiated only after stakeholder alignment on discovery outcomes.

The cheat for an architect is to Identify the 3-5 discovery candidate​, that can be delivered in the first sprint successfully. The exploratory 'fail fast' cases should be put for later sprints.

To surmise, as SAP continues to embed AI capabilities into S/4HANA and SAP BTP, the success of enterprise AI initiatives increasingly depends on disciplined discovery rather than experimental implementation. A structured, discovery-first AI assessment enables organizations to align AI use cases with SAP business processes, data realities, and organizational readiness. Joule will accelerate the SAP AI adaptations through its customer base.

For SAP Enterprise Architects, this six-step Discovery-First approach provides a repeatable and scalable framework that complements S/4HANA transformations and positions SAP’s built-in AI capabilities for sustainable value realization.

entry.title: Re: 6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discovery-First Approach
entry.content:
@TrijoySaikia @dear Trijoy, thank you for sharing your detailed perspective!  It’s well drafted! If I can add one suggestion from my side, it would be : we need step 0.

Step 0 includes talking to the business to understand their big ticket priorities and then breaking them down into possible use cases that support achieving those priorities. Doing business value assessments at Step 4 is bit too late in my opinion.  If you really want to productionise a use case, you don’t need a pipeline of 10 use cases, just need 1-2 high value use cases which business wants and will support! 🙏

Again, thank you for sharing your thoughts with the community!

entry.title: Re: Run Statutory Reports App: fetches the data from the...
entry.content:
Dear all,

 

Please note, data archiving is used to delete data at the end of its lifecycle and to block and delete personal data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Archiving moves the personal data from the database to archive files if the end of purpose is reached. In doing so, the personal data is implicitly marked as blocked. Blocked data has access restrictions to prevent further unauthorized processing.

 

The 'Manage Archiving Variants' app, choose the archiving object and schedule archiving.

 

We can use the archiving object SRF_TASK for archiving reporting tasks in statutory reporting.

 

Please refer the below help document for more information,

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4de200b26d5d42bbacae69c6bf6b9923/cb2ee9a6517f499299e8c03fad46e373.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

 

Best regards,

Atanu

SAP Support - S/4HANA Cloud

entry.title: Re: Prerequisites for a supplier to participate in OCI 5....
entry.content:
Good day @KeLaw 

Thank you for your question

Yes, there are supplier side prerequisites that you should consider. When you look at the blogs you attached, you can recognise various defined sections in ensuring you can successfully implement your project. In summary, they fall into three buckets that can be defined as: technical capability of OCI, Authentication and access, Parameter handling and data protection, content quality and data completeness, Images and attachments.

In public cloud, OCI 4.0 will support your classic catalog punch out for Self Service Procurement. You user are then able to open the supplier catalog, fill their cars and return items into the purchase requisition. See, Settings for Web Services & OCI for more insights.

For OCI 5.0, this is relevant if you want to import catalog items and cross catalog searches are possible. It uses JSON over HTTP or file upload to support catalog data replication

In reference to the buckets mentioned earlier, you may consider this as a checklist for your supplier.

Technical capability:

For OCI 4.0 punch out, your supplier must provide a HTTPS catalog entry URL that your users can reach. They must also support the OCI roundtrip and return the cart back to SAP. See Settings for Web Services.

For OCI 5.0, your supplier must provide catalog content that matches the designed format as mentioned above.

Authentication and access:  

The Schedule Import of Catalog Data and Settings for Web Services provides details/prerequisites on how SAP stores the authentication parameters. So, you will need to agree with your supplier on how the catalog session is authenticated.

Parameter handling and data protection:

SAP sends certain parameters such as language, currency, return URL, etc and your supplier must accept those. You can use certain BAdI to control OCI parameters in the outbound call if you want to restrict what user data is sent. This Blog has some good insights: Employee Self Service Procurement in S4 HANA with Catalogs hosted in External System.

Content quality and data completeness:

Make sure you align with your suppliers on their ability to provide quality data such as Product ID, UoM, price, currency, tax logic, attachments, etc.

Images and attachments:

Considering you will be carrying out cross catalog searches and will need attachments and images, you will need to use a Content Management Service endpoint.

To summarise:

  • Your supplier must support OCI 4.0 for classic punch out.
  • Same for OCI 5.0 and must provide catalog data as JSON over HTTP or file.
  • Make sure you set up the supplier catalog in Settings for Web Service
  • Ensure to schedule catalog import and delivered contents are sent through accessible endpoint.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Migration of Open Items with VAT Codes into SAP S/4HANA with Migration Cockpit
entry.content:
Current Situation

As part of an SAP migration project from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA, open items for customers (AR), vendors (AP), and G/L accounts (balance sheet and P&L) are migrated using the Migration Cockpit with the staging table approach and XML template files.

During this process, it becomes apparent that some open items in the SAP ERP source system contain a VAT (tax) code. However, the migration of these VAT codes is technically limited or problematic, especially when no corresponding tax-relevant G/L line item exists.

Reasons for Not Migrating VAT Codes

The VAT code is currently not migrated for the following reasons:

  1. Closed VAT reporting period in the source system
    The VAT return for the closed period 12/20XX must be executed in the SAP ERP system, as only there all tax-relevant document line items for the final reporting period are fully available.

  2. Technical restrictions of the Migration Cockpit
    The Migration Cockpit (staging table approach) does not appear to support a consistent migration of VAT codes for open items when no tax-relevant G/L line item is transferred together with the customer or vendor line.

Error Message During Migration

When attempting to migrate open items with a VAT code, the following system message occurs:

“Tax code XX is not contained in any G/L account line item”
Message class: FF
Message number: 753

System Diagnosis

The document contains a customer or vendor line item with a VAT code, but no corresponding tax-relevant G/L line item.
Since tax line items are derived from the accounting document, the system considers this an inconsistent posting.

SAP further explains that such postings may lead to:

  • Cash discount bases being set to zero if not entered manually

  • Incorrect or incomplete tax recalculation during cash discount clearing

  • Tax reporting inconsistencies in the target system

Current Technical Workaround

By changing the message control in transaction OBA5, the error can be downgraded to a warning, allowing the open items to be migrated despite the inconsistency.

Open Question and Business Risk

This leads to the central question:

Can automatic tax correction during payment runs (including cash discount calculation) still be performed correctly in SAP S/4HANA if open items are migrated without a tax-relevant G/L line item or without the original VAT code?

If the VAT code is not migrated, this may cause functional limitations in SAP S/4HANA, especially in:

  • Payment runs for customers and vendors

  • Cash discount processing

  • Automatic tax corrections and tax reporting

Key Questions

  • What are the technically and functionally correct approaches to migrate open items with VAT codes from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA?

  • What options does the Migration Cockpit (staging table approach) offer for transferring VAT codes in open items?

  • What are the advantages and disadvantages of each approach
    (e.g. migrating VAT codes vs. deliberately omitting them)?

  • What are the impacts on downstream processes, especially payment runs, cash discount handling, and tax adjustments in SAP S/4HANA?

Objective

The objective is to identify a technically sound, audit-compliant, and process-stable solution for migrating open items with VAT codes that ensures correct financial processing and tax handling in SAP S/4HANA.

entry.title: BOM Maintenance in S/4 HANA Public Cloud using next-gen FIORI Apps
entry.content:
• Introduction:
  • Feature comparison FIORI vs Transactions
  • F1813A: Maintain Bill of Material (Version 2)
  • Copy BOM using base timeline
  • Plant allocation to Material BOM
  • Change documents
  • Maintain components using prefilled Excel
  • Conclusion:

Introduction:

In classical ERP, BOM maintenance is usually done via widely known transactions like CS01 / CS02 / CS03.

For other processes in BOM like explosion, multilevel maintenance etc. there are separate classic transactions available. However, in present world of Cloud ERP, business users demand a flexible, intuitive and feature enriched FIORI application to handle such day-to-day maintenance tasks. 

At present, there are various FIORI apps already available on S/4 HANA Public Cloud to handle classic transactional based activities.

In this blog series, we will get a guidance to use those features in corresponding FIORI apps which are available since years, and we will also go through the latest released FIORI apps in details.

Feature comparison FIORI vs Transactions

Following table will illustrate the various features which are available in different transactions in classic ERP and corresponding FIORI application in the S/4 HANA Public Cloud:

 

FeatureTransactionFIORI App in Public Cloud
BOM creation / modification (Material BOM)CS01 / CS02 / CS03

F1813: Maintain Bill of Material

F1813A: Maintain Bill of Material (Version 2)

BOM creation / modification (Sales Order BOM)CS61 / CS62 / CS63 (NA in Public cloud)F4339A: Manage Order Bill of Material (Version 2)
BOM creation / modification (WBS BOM)CS71 / CS72 / CS73 (NA in Public cloud)F7971: Maintain WBS Bill of Material
Plant allocation to Material BOMCS07 / CS08

Assign Plant in F1813 / F1813A

Unassign Plant in F1813 / F1813A

 

BOM Explosion level by levelCS11F4584: Explode Bill of Material
Summarized BOMCS13F4584: Explode Bill of Material
BOM Comparison CS14F5938: Compare Bills of Material
Single level Where-used-ListCS15F2214: Material Where-Used List
Sales Order BOM ExplosionCSK1 / CSK2 / CSK3(NA in Public cloud)F4584: Explode Bill of Material
Change Documents for Material BOMCS80(NA in Public cloud)F1813A: Maintain Bill of Material (Version 2)

Apart from above list of FIORI apps, there are various applications available for Mass maintenance of BOM Header and components in background mode which are quite helpful.

Let's start the series with our first set of maintenance apps with their top features. 

F1813A: Maintain Bill of Material (Version 2)

For application supported features and required roles are mentioned in app documentation on FIORI app library:

Product Features: Maintain Bill of Material (Version 2)

Here, we will understand some latest features and innovations which are exclusively available in these apps.

  • Copy BOM using base timeline

There are scenarios where one single BOM has multiple instances based on different dates. It is possible that a BOM can have different set of components or different data available on various properties which are valid only on a specific date.

If we want to create new BOMs by copying such BOM as a reference, it would be relevant to select a date which only copy the corresponding base line changes. It was possible in classical transactions like CS01 and now, similar feature is also supported in FIORI apps - Maintain Bill of Material (Version 2).

e.g. BOM for Centrifugal Pump would have 16 components valid on 20.12.2025.  However, component for flow sensor has quantity 10 EA valid from 06.09.2025 and also, has document item (0160) while the same BOM has component for flow sensor with quantity 2 EA when It is loaded with validity of 01.09.2025.

Valid-from 20.12.205              Valid from 01.09.2025

If we now copy this BOM, we can get appropriate components in the copied BOM based on base line selection date.

Steps to copy a BOM using base timeline

1. Select the BOM and press "Copy BOM" from toolbar

2. Enter Material, Plant, Usage, validity for the target BOM, Option to copy the components and base timeline for the selected BOM:

Spoiler
P.S.: By default, current system date would be shown in target validity and base line validity. It will also be changed with the validity of the change number if corresponding Change numbers will be provided. 

3. Press "Copy BOM" in the dialog with default date. Components valid from this date would be copied over to target BOM in draft version i.e. component for flow sensor with quantity 10 EA and document item.

Copied BOM in draft with baseline date 20.12.2025

In Step 2 above, if baseline date will be entered as 01.09.2025, component for flow sensor with quantity 2 EA will be copied.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  • Plant allocation to Material BOM

As illustrated in the Feature comparison table above, there are separate transactions available in ERP to allocate a plant to Material BOM and delete the existing allocation. We can achieve this in single feature in this FIORI app using "Plant assignment"

1. Select a BOM and press on menu button "Plant assignment" on the toolbar:

2. Press on "Assign" menu option to allocate a plant and enter the plant in the dialog:

3. Press "Assign Plant" button and new BOM allocation with plant value will be created

4. If we want to remove plant allocations, press "Unassign Plant" menu action in step 1 and confirm the removal.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  • Change documents 

When we do changes in a BOM, change documents get created and saved in the system. It is quite helpful for auditors to track the change history. In classic ERP, we could get it using CS80 transaction (as mentioned in Feature comparison section).

In this FIORI app, we have a new section called "Change Documents" which captures all changes.

Grouping of Component changes:

If there are multiple changes in different components and we would like to group changes for each component together, we can create a variant by adding new field (Table Key) from personalization:

Export as excel for all changes:

Using Excel export button toolbar, we can download all changes done in the specific BOM as excel. Please note that columns on excel will depend on visible columns exposed on the table before exporting.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  • Maintain components using prefilled Excel

Several times, business users prefer to use a prefilled excel file to quickly create components of a BOM. This FIORI app supports a nice excel paste feature. It is possible to create new components as well as update existing components using the excel data.

Spoiler
Please note that excel should be aligned with the same no. of columns as in FIORI app for Components. Sequence should also be the same. 
Create new components:

1. Prepare excel with new component details to be created

2. Copy excel data to clipboard starting from 1st cell till end i.e. A2 -> K3 as shown in step 1.

3. Open BOM app in Edit mode and press on "Paste" button as shown below:

4. New components will be created in draft and highlighted copied from the clipboard:

5. Once saved, components will be persisted in the BOM.

Update existing components:

1. Prepare excel with existing components details and provide values to be updated.

2. Copy excel data to clipboard starting from 1st cell till end i.e. A2 -> K3 as shown in step 1.

3. Open BOM app in Edit mode, select cells which needs updating of data. 

Spoiler
Hint: As we want to update 1st two components of the BOM, we can start selecting the last cell (Change Number) of 2nd row, press left key in the mouse and keep selecting till 1st cell (Item Number) of 1st row.

4. Press "Paste" button. It will only update editable cells which are part of clipboard via copied data set.

5. Once saved, components will be updated in the BOM.

Spoiler
We can also use "Export Table" button in the toolbar to download the exact format of the excel which is aligned with table columns of the component in FIORI app and prepare the excel data for modification of components. Please note that properties which must be updated for components, shall be available in table column. If required properties are not available in standard layout, it is recommended to create your own variant using personalization and export it afterwards.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:

There are other plenty of other features which we can check in upcoming part for this blog series. With this version, we have tried to highlight some latest and useful features to maintain BOM master data using latest FIORI apps.

To continue this Blog series and illustrated in the section "Feature comparison", we've seen various other useful apps which are available in S/4 HANA Public Cloud and providing the same features as in classical transactions. We will publish the similar feature guides to cover more FIORI apps in SCM Core Manufacturing Bill of Material.

entry.title: Re: Replicate Public holiday and leave in employee time s...
entry.content:
Hello @Shahana

Thank you for your question

Here is a general information, Workforce Availability integration is designed for staffing availability and not for creating leave or public holiday entries in My Timesheet.

Answer to your question on how you can reflect your requirements:

Yes, you can do that through standard integration and not by posting time entries. Best practice is:

  1. Leave and holidays should come from SuccessFactors Time Off and holiday calendar, which in this case represents the time management system. The timesheet is then displayed in S4H through Consolidated Time Recording. See the following reference for more details: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-employee-central/implementing-time-management-in-sap-successfactors/consolidated-time-recording-with-sap-s-4hana?locale=en-US
  2. If you try to push holidays as time entries, you would be using the Workforce Timesheet API but that is meant for time entry CRUD and not for maintaining holiday calendars or leave entitlements.

Answer to the question about being able to post all public holidays:

In standard, there is no need for that and I would not recommend it. You normally derive public holidays from the holiday calendar and work schedule based on the region you are in, not posted as individual time entries per employee. This also has an impact on the targeted hours shown in the timesheet UI. See the following reference for more details: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-employee-central/implementing-time-management-in-sap-successfactors/consolidated-time-recording-with-sap-s-4hana?locale=en-US

If you want your holidays to be based on a particular region, you should maintain different holiday calendar and assign them through work schedules per region and not by generating yearly postings for each user.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Using ChatGPT Personalization Settings for Effective SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting
entry.content:
Introduction
SAP Analytics Cloud scripting, especially with BW Live data, is sensitive to small mistakes.
Implicit type conversion, reused variables, or unclear logic can easily cause runtime errors or unexpected results.
To avoid this, I configured ChatGPT personalization settings specifically for SAC scripting.
These settings guide ChatGPT to generate safe, predictable, and production-ready scripts instead of generic JavaScript-like code.
This blog explains the key personalization rules and how they help in daily SAC development.

1. Enforcing Explicit Data Type Conversion
Why This Matters
Text Input widgets in SAC always return strings.
Using them directly in calculations or variable feeding is unsafe.
By instructing ChatGPT to never use auto type conversion, the generated scripts become stable.

Personalization Rule
• Always use ConvertUtils for string, number, and date conversion
• Never rely on implicit conversion

Resulting Script Pattern
var inputVal = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_1.getValue());
This avoids:
• Runtime errors
• BW variable failures
• Unexpected results

2. Treating Every Event as Independent
Why This Matters
In SAC, scripts run in event-based isolation.
Global variables or reused variables can break execution order.
By forcing ChatGPT to treat each event independently, scripts remain predictable.

Personalization Rule
• Declare all variables explicitly in each event
• Do not reuse variables implicitly
• Do not use global variables

Resulting Script Pattern
var dsTarget = Table_Main.getDataSource();
Each script becomes:
• Self-contained
• Easy to debug
• Safe during future changes

3. Forcing Simple and Minimal Logic
Why This Matters
Complex loops and nested conditions reduce readability and increase risk in BW Live stories.
By instructing ChatGPT to always start with simple and minimal working scripts, the output remains practical.

Personalization Rule
• Always provide simple, minimal, and working scripts first
• Avoid unnecessary loops and complex logic

Resulting Benefit
• Scripts are easier to review
• Performance is more predictable
• Business users face fewer issues

4. Enforcing Correct SAC API Usage
Why This Matters
Generic JavaScript examples often misuse SAC APIs.
Incorrect use of DataSource APIs causes silent failures.
Personalization ensures that ChatGPT:
• Uses DataSource API correctly
• Applies feed binding and dimension filtering properly

Resulting Script Pattern
dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY", dimList);
Instead of unsupported or incorrect logic.

5. Strict Commenting and Readability Rules
Why This Matters
SAC scripts are often maintained by multiple people.
Clear comments reduce dependency on the original developer.

Personalization Rule
• Use /* */ for multiline comments
• Use // for single-line comments

Resulting Script Pattern
/* Apply dimension filter safely */
dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY", dimList);
This improves:
• Maintainability
• Knowledge transfer
• Long-term support

6. Aligning Output with BW Live Reality
Why This Matters
BW Live behaves differently from import models.
Scripts must respect:
• Live refresh behavior
• Variable dependency
• Performance constraints
Personalization settings guide ChatGPT to generate scripts that:
• Refresh data explicitly
• Avoid unsupported shortcuts
• Respect BW Live limitations

Conclusion
ChatGPT can be a powerful assistant for SAP Analytics Cloud scripting, but only when it is guided correctly.
By defining clear personalization settings focused on explicit typing, isolation, simplicity, and correct API usage, the generated scripts become reliable and production-ready.
For BW Live scripting, these settings are not optional. They are essential.

entry.title: Capability of deactivating quality inspection on Movement type for goods receipt in EWM
entry.content:
SAP Extended warehouse management (EWM) supports quality inspection at goods receipt of materials in decentralized as well as embedded EWM. Relevant for quality inspection on goods receipt is set at material master and / or quality inspection rule. Refer my blog https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/simplification-with-quality-inspection-in-embedded-extended-warehouse/ba-p/13436009 for more details.

Quality inspection is necessary on receipt for certain materials when receiving materials from external vendor or so. However, this quality is not needed (in most cases) while receiving goods in EWM managed warehouse on

  • Initial upload of stock
  • Transfer posting from one storage location (A) to another storage location (B) within the same plant  (as materials have already been inspected while receiving in storage location A

However, inspection lot gets created on transfer posting between storage locations within the same plant as in below image. Movement type is 311 in this case of transfer posting.

Quality inspection lot appears in the document flow of the inbound delivery created on transfer posting as in below image.

With S/4HANA 2025 release, it is now feasible to switch off quality inspection while receiving goods for specific movement types as depicted in below process flow.

Checkbox ‘QM not active’ has now been flagged for movement type 311 in IMG path Quality Management -> Quality Inspection -> Inspection Lot Creation -> Inspection for Goods Movements -> Deactivate Quality Inspection for a Movement Type.

Checkbox ‘ QM Deact. MvmtTyp’ has now been activated Inspection object type 4 in IMG path SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Cross-Process Settings -> Quality Management -> Basics and Integration -> Define and Activate Warehouse-Dependent IOTs.

A new transfer posting has now been executed which created the inbound delivery 180001686 as in below image.

Goods receipt  on inbound delivery is now posted , but no inspection lot appears in the document flow of the inbound delivery.

A new field ‘Quality inspection not active’ has also been added to the item level of inbound delivery and it states that the same has been deactivated by movement type as in below image.

This blog is based on my personal tests , observations , insights in S/4HANA 2025 release. Will appreciate your feedback / comments.

entry.title: Re: Inspection lot stuck in QI even with UD made.
entry.content: Hi! It sounds like the inspection lots are stuck due to a mismatch between the system’s posting logic and the lot status. Even if the “to be posted” tab shows zero, sometimes background jobs or incomplete confirmations can block the stock posting. I’d suggest checking for any pending batch jobs, reviewing the material document logs, and ensuring that the usage decision was fully confirmed for all relevant quantities. If everything looks correct but the lot remains stuck, creating a support ticket with SAP might be necessary to clear the block.

entry.title: Re: Performance Issue in SAP Commerce APIs Resolved Using...
entry.content:
Below is the checklist to validate and fix.

Review Fastly VCL configuration - Ensure consistent caching rules across all edge locations
Add monitoring - Track response times by country, query parameters
Standardize API calls - Fix frontend to consistently use either ?varientcode= or ?varientcode=value(Based on your customization)
Check database - Verify if the specific country has significantly more data, causing slow queries
Review indexes - Ensure proper database indexes exist for country-specific queries

Note: The real fix is proper cache configuration, not bypassing cache entirely (which defeats the CDN's purpose).

entry.title: Re: Partial Good Receipt in tcode VL32N
entry.content:
Hi @esterwang ,
SAP standard, VL32N does not support partial Goods Receipt — the putaway quantity must equal the delivery quantity. To handle partial GR, SAP recommends using MIGO/MB0A or customizing inbound delivery processes. Best practices involve either splitting deliveries or configuring tolerance/warehouse settings depending on whether you use Inventory Management (IM) or Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)

While VL32N itself does not allow partial GR, there are workarounds/configurations. Use MIGO/MB0A: These transactions allow posting partial GR against inbound deliveries.
Delivery tolerances: In PO/item settings, you can define under-delivery tolerances. However, these apply at PO level, not VL32N inbound delivery GR. Item category/movement type: Customizing movement types (e.g., 101 vs. 109) can allow partial receipts in IM, but VL32N still enforces full receipt.
Warehouse settings (EWM): In EWM, inbound delivery handling supports partial GR and putaway. You can confirm partial quantities during warehouse task confirmation

SAP recommends the following approaches. Use MIGO for GR: Post partial GR directly in MIGO referencing the inbound delivery. This ensures correct document flow and inventory updates. Split inbound deliveries: If partial receipt is expected, create multiple inbound deliveries (e.g., 90 BAR + 10 BAR). Each can be receipted separately.

Leverage EWM functionality: In EWM-managed warehouses, partial GR is supported during putaway confirmation. This is the preferred best practice for advanced warehouse scenarios. Avoid mixing transactions: SAP advises not to mix VL32N with MIGO for the same delivery, as it can cause inconsistencies

entry.title: How to configure strictly "monitoring-only" access for specific SAP CPI integration flows
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,
I need assistance with a specific security configuration requirement in SAP Integration Suite (CPI).

Goal:
I want to grant a specific group of users the ability to monitor the runtime status of a selected set of integration flows, but they must be strictly restricted from:
  1. Editing, deploying, or deleting these iFlows (no design-time access).
  2. Viewing sensitive runtime data such as message payloads, attachments, or trace contents.
They should only be able to see the basic message processing logs (status: Completed, Failed, Error, timestamp, etc.).
Current Understanding/Setup Attempt:
  • I know that standard roles like PI_Integration_Developer provide design access, which I want to avoid.
  • I plan to assign the users monitoring-focused roles like AuthGroup.BusinessExpert or esbmessagestorage.read.
  • I understand that Access Policies are used to restrict visibility of payload data.
The Challenge/Question:
If I assign only standard monitoring roles and use an Access Policy to restrict content visibility:
  1. Will users with just the standard monitoring roles automatically be prevented from viewing the message payloads of iFlows covered by the policy?
  2. Do I need to create a negative access policy or simply ensure these users are not assigned the custom role associated with the positive access policy?
  3. Is this combination of standard roles and access policies the correct, best practice method to achieve monitoring-only (status-only) visibility for designated iFlows?
I want to confirm the exact roles and policy configuration needed to ensure a user can access the "Monitor" UI and see the list of messages for specific flows, but receive an "Unauthorized" error if they attempt to open the message content details.

Thank you in advance for any clarification!

entry.title: Generate Client Certificate for Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities via SAP BTP
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

  1. Access to the relevant subaccount in which you want to generate a certificate.
  2.  Admin privileges for the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition system.

Generate Client Certificate 

  1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Connectivity ➡️ Destination Certificates ➡️ click on Create
  2. Under the Generation Method section, choose External service

  3. Under the Generation Details, fill in the following fields:
    1. Name – The name you would like to assign to the certificate.
    2. File Extension – Leave this field as is, with the value PEM.
    3. Validity – Select the desired duration; I chose one year.
    4. Password – Although this field is optional, it is required to complete the installation in the system.
    5. Automatic Renewal – Set according to your preference; the default value is "On".
  4.  Click on Create.
  5. You will get the following screen:

Download the Client Certificate 

To download the certificate we generated along with its private key, we’ll need to use the Destination Service (Cloud Foundry) API.
The full certificate isn’t available for download through the SAP BTP admin console.
 
You can find the full API documentation on: https://api.sap.com/api/SAP_CP_CF_Connectivity_Destination/overview 

The API URL is: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.<your_region>.hana.ondemand.com/destination configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates
 
In my example, the region is eu10.
 

For authentication, we need to create an instance of the Destination Service and generate a service key if one does not already exist in our subaccount.

  1. Create a Destension service instance for the authentication details:
    1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Services ➡️ Instances and Subscription ➡️ click on Create.
    2.  Choose the "Destination Service" service, select the "lite" plan, and use a space you have authorization to create an instance in ➡️ click on Create.
    3. After creation, you will see a new instance 
    4. Create a new service key, enter the Service Key Name ➡️ Create.
       

    5. Click on ... ➡️ View
       
The authentication method required for this API is Bearer token authentication.
In my example, I use the Postman client, but you can also work with any other API tool that supports OAuth 2.0 authentication.
 
For the authentication with OAuth 2.0, enter the following fields (when using Pastman):
  1. Grant Type = "Client Credentials" 
  2. Access Token URL = "url" in our service key JSON file with the prefix "/oauth/token"
  3. Client ID = "clientid" in our service key JSON file.
  4. Client Secret = "clientsecret" in our service key JSON file.
  5. Client Authentication = "Send as Basic Auth header".
  6. Click on Get New Access Token ➡️ on the new pop-up window click on Use Token

After we have a token, we can call the API to get our certificate:

The method is GET, and the URL will be https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/{Your Certificate Name}.

In my example, the URL will be: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/J4D_Guide.pem.

The response for the call needs to be like:   

We will get the full certificate, including the private key in base64, and now we need to convert it to text and save it as a PEM certificate.

 
For the conversion, I'm using the terminal on my computer with the command:
echo "base64string" | base64 --decode​

You will need to replace the "base64string" with your certificate in base64.

The decoded result will be like the example below:

I copied the full result to a text editor and saved it with the PEM extension. 

Load the Client Certificate to the SAP S/4HANA private cloud 

After we have the PEM certificate with the private key, we can proceed and load the certificate to the ABAP system.

  1. Enter the "STRUST" transaction ➡️ on the top toolbar, and click on "Environment" ➡️ and choose "SSL Client Identities of System "

     

  2.  ➡️ Click on the change button. 
  3. Click on "New Entries" ➡️ Enter an Identity and Desctiption ➡️ Click Enter ➡️ Click on Save.
  4. You will need a transport request to save the changes, so create a new one.
  5. The new entry will appear on the left panel
  6. If you are in display mode, click on the change button. once again.
  7. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ➡️  Import ➡️ PKCS#8/PEM 
  8. In the file browser, choose the file you created in the previous step.
  9. Enter the certification password as entered in the SAP BTP admin portal.
  10. You will see the certificate details:
  11. Click on the check mark to proceed to the next step.
  12. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ➡️ ➡️ Save As...
  13. On the pop-up, choose the SSL Client with the client we created before ➡️ Click on the check mark 
  14. Click on the Save button on the toolbar.

We’re done 😊
Now all that remains is to import the certificates from the BTP Trust Store and continue configuring Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities.

entry.title: Use Custom Roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Introduction: With the increasing adoption of Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition (PCE), customers are now looking beyond standard business roles and want to control access using custom roles. This becomes especially important when Joule is enabled for selective users, specific business scenarios, or restricted transactional access.

However, configuring custom roles for Joule is not entirely straightforward. It requires a clear understanding of role content, content exposure, and identity provisioning, all of which must work together to ensure Joule can access the required business data and applications.

In this blog, I will walk you through three key topics that will help you successfully use custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA PCE:

1️. What a Custom Role Must Contain for Joule to Work Correctly

When using custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, the role definition plays a critical role in determining what Joule can see, understand, and execute. Unlike traditional Fiori usage, Joule depends heavily on Launchpad content, semantic navigation, and backend OData access.

Below are the three key aspects you must consider while designing a custom role.

When creating a custom role, it is essential to ensure that it contains the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs. You can check this SAP Note for the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

To verify this, you should always check the business catalogs that are assigned to your custom role. Business catalogs define which applications, semantic objects, and target mappings are available to the user - and these are what Joule relies on for navigation and execution.

For example, in this scenario, I created a single custom role by reusing a standard SAP business catalog that already contains all Purchase Order related semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

 

By including this required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs in the custom role, Joule can correctly:

  • Resolve Purchase Order related intents
  • Navigate using the appropriate semantic object and action
  • Launch the correct Fiori applications without additional configuration

If you plan to use a Master Role and Derived Role approach, you can create the master role in the same way as described above, ensuring it contains all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app IDs.

Once the master role is created, you can then derive one or more derived roles from it. The derived roles inherit all the authorization content from the master role, while allowing you to maintain organizational-level restrictions if required.

I have also created a derived role from the master role, as shown in the screenshot below. The derived role inherits all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app mappings from the master role, ensuring consistent access behavior for Joule while allowing role assignment at the user level.

2️. How to Perform Content Exposure for Custom Roles

🔹V2 Content Exposure (Recommended)

If you are on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition 2023 FPS01 or higher, you must expose your content using Content Exposure Version 2 (V2).

Before exposing content, ensure the following prerequisites are in place.

🔹Activate Required ICF Services

Make sure the following ICF service is active:

  • /sap/bc/http

You can verify and activate this using transaction SICF.

🔹Maintain Design-Time Destination in SAP BTP

In SAP BTP, the design-time destination must include the following service endpoint URL:

<host>/sap/bc/http/ui2/flp_content_exposure/entities

This endpoint is required for SAP Build Work Zone to read exposed content from S/4HANA.

🔹Activate HTTP Service via UCON

Since this is an HTTP-based service, it may need explicit activation.

  • Use transaction UCON_HTTP_SERVICES
  • Activate the service:
  • /UI2/FLP_CONTENT_EXPOSURE

This step is mandatory if the service is restricted by UCON.

🔹Required Authorization Roles

Ensure the following roles are assigned:

  • Administrator Role
    The administrator must have SAP Fiori Launchpad administration authorizations to expose content to SAP BTP.
  • SAP_FLP_EXP_USER
    Assign this role to the technical user used by SAP Build Work Zone.
    This role allows the user to read and consume exposed content.

🔹Which Roles Should Be Exposed?

To expose roles, use transaction:

/UI2/CDM3_EXP_SCOPE

Perform the following steps:

  1. Choose Exposure Version = Version 2
  2. Select roles under Areas
    • All selected roles across areas will be exposed
    • You can expose individual roles or group multiple roles under one area

Role Exposure Rules

  • Custom Single Role
    → Directly expose the custom role
  • Master & Derived Role Model
    → Expose the Master Role only
    (Derived roles cannot be exposed independently)
  • Alternative Approach
    If you do not want to expose the master role:
    • Create a Composite Role
    • Add the required derived roles
    • Expose the composite role

This approach provides flexibility while keeping role design clean.

🔹Verification Steps to Ensure Joule Can Consume the Content

Once the content exposure is completed:

  1. Go to SAP Build Work Zone
  2. Perform a content refresh / update

  3. Verify that:
    • Exposed apps are visible
    • Semantic navigation works
    • Apps can be launched from Work Zone

If the content is visible and accessible in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume and use the exposed content correctly.

3️. How to Set Up Identity Provisioning (IPS) to Test Custom Roles

Finally, to validate custom roles with Joule, you must configure the Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) job so that users and roles from SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition are provisioned correctly to SAP Build Work Zone.

In most productive systems, executing a full IPS job can take a significant amount of time, as it processes all users and all roles available in the source S/4HANA PCE system. For testing and validation purposes, it is recommended to limit the scope of provisioning using filters.

🔹Why Use Filters in IPS?

By applying filters, you can:

  • Provision only specific test users
  • Provision only relevant custom roles
  • Reduce job execution time

🔹Recommended IPS Filters for Testing

In the IPS source system configuration, add the following filters.

Role Filter

Use this filter to provision only the required custom roles.

abap.role.name.filter = (?i)^(ROLE1|ROLE2|ROLE3).*

🔹This filter:

  • Is case-insensitive ((?i))
  • Provisions only roles matching the specified role names

If you are using a Master and Derived Role model and assign derived roles to users, then you must maintain only the derived roles in this filter. Master roles should not be included unless they are directly assigned to users.

User Filter

Use this filter to provision only the test users.

abap.user.name.filter = ^(USER1|USER2|USER3).*

🔹Execute and Validate the IPS Job

After maintaining the filters:

  1. Run the IPS job
  2. Monitor the job status for errors
  3. Verify in SAP Build Work Zone that:
    • Test users are provisioned
    • Correct roles are assigned

  4. Log in as a test user and validate Joule behavior

If the users and roles are visible and correctly assigned in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume the exposed content and execute actions as expected.

entry.title: Streaming in SAP API Management: Extended Guide
entry.content:
•  Why Streaming Matters

By default, APIM buffers request/response payloads so policies can operate on the full message. Non-streamed payloads are limited to ~10 MB. When payloads exceed the buffer, APIM returns a fault. Streaming lifts this buffer by passing data through without payload modifications, allowing up to ~500 MB per direction (subject to connection stability).

Key Limits

  • Non-streamed request/response: up to 10 MB
  •  Streamed request/response: up to ~500 MB
  •  Header limits: Request headers ~18 KB; Response headers ~25 KB
  •  Resource files (XSL/JS/Python) ~15 MB (design-time)

Note: When streaming is enabled, policies that read or transform the payload are bypassed and may fail on large payloads.

  •  Properties Explained

request.streaming.enabled (ProxyEndpoint & TargetEndpoint):
false: buffer requests; payload policies operate.
true: stream request payload to target; payload-reading policies in ProxyEndpoint request flow are bypassed.

response.streaming.enabled (ProxyEndpoint & TargetEndpoint):
false: buffer responses; payload policies operate.
true: stream response payload back to client; payload-reading policies in ProxyEndpoint response flow are bypassed.

  •  Configure via UI (APIM Portal)

Steps:
1. Go to Develop → APIs → select your proxy.
2. Open Proxy Endpoint tab → Properties → Add:
   • Name: request.streaming.enabled, Value: true
   • Name: response.streaming.enabled, Value: true
3. Open Target Endpoint tab → Properties → Add same properties.
4. Save and redeploy the proxy.

  • Configure via XML (Proxy & Target Definitions)

Proxy Endpoint sample:

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8' standalone='yes'?>
<ProxyEndPoint default='true'>
  <name>default</name>
  <base_path>/my/api</base_path>
  <properties>
    <property><name>request.streaming.enabled</name><value>true</value></property>
    <property><name>response.streaming.enabled</name><value>true</value></property>
  </properties>
</ProxyEndPoint>

Target Endpoint sample:

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8' standalone='yes'?>
<TargetEndPoint>
  <name>default</name>
  <url>https://backend.example.com/v1</url>
  <properties>
    <property><name>request.streaming.enabled</name><value>true</value></property>
    <property><name>response.streaming.enabled</name><value>true</value></property>
  </properties>
</TargetEndPoint>

  •  Error 'Screenshots' (Fault Payloads)

Non-streamed payload exceeds 10 MB:

Streaming enabled but payload-transform policy attached:

  •  Policies: What Works / What to Avoid

Works with streaming: Verify API Key, OAuth verification, Access Control, basic header logging (no body read).
Avoid with streaming: JSON↔XML transforms, schema validations, masking/redaction, payload enrichment — these force buffering or fail.

  •  Patterns with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI)

Use APIM for pass-through streaming of large payloads. Perform transformations/validations in CPI or backend. For very large datasets, consider paging, split-and-collect, or batch processing.

Optional: Streaming + gzip + chunked

Compress the entire payload first, then stream using chunked transfer (Content-Encoding: gzip; Transfer-Encoding: chunked; no Content-Length).

  •  Troubleshooting

  • TooBigBody: Enable streaming for the affected direction; remove payload-transform policies.
  • Policies inconsistent >10 MB: Redesign to avoid body access in streamed flows.
  • Timeouts: Adjust TargetEndpoint transport properties (connect.timeout.millis, io.timeout.millis) per backend latency.

  •  FAQs

Q: Can I enable streaming on all proxies?
A: Technically yes, but only enable when required; payload policies will be bypassed.
Q: Maximum streamed size?
A: ~500 MB per request/response direction; ensure stable connections.
Q: Can I transform payload while streaming?
A: Not recommended in APIM; move transforms to CPI/backend.

  •  Pre-deployment Checklist

☐ Identify direction (request/response) needing streaming.
☐ Remove payload-inspecting policies from streamed flows.
☐ Tune timeouts for long streams.
☐ Communicate design impacts to teams (no in-proxy transforms).
☐ Validate with large test payloads.

Disclaimer

This content reflects implementation experience and references official SAP Help pages. Always consult SAP Help for the latest guidance and product limits.

References

SAP Help: Enable Streaming of Requests and Responses in an API Proxy – https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/enable-streaming-of-requests-and-responses-in-api-proxy

SAP Help: Proxy Endpoint Properties – https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-api-management/sap-api-management/proxy-endpoint-properties

SAP Help: Limits in API Management – https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-api-management/sap-api-management/limits

SAP Help (Neo) – Sample streaming configuration – https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-api-management/sap-api-management-for-neo-environment/enable-streaming-of-requests-and-responses-in-api-proxy

entry.title: Re: SM12
entry.content:
Dear @laxmiprasad_rkhasnis,

1. Option in CBC

SAP recommendation is procedural BUT not technical deletion:

  • Ensure the same SSCUI/app is not open in another tab/session by you or someone else
  • Avoid having the same config activity open in parallel while one session is still in edit mode
  • Then wait SAP notes the lock is auto-released and the timing can depend on the cleanup job timing and current system load

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2665646

Also SAP explains this occurs when multiple users/apps save at the same time to the same target. The resolution is:

  • Wait until the other update completes, then retry
  • Avoid simultaneous saving in different applications

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2747494

2. Option when Business data locks in Fiori apps

SAP recommended approach in Public Cloud:

  • If locked by a named business user: ask them to save/cancel and exit the object, and close any parallel browser tabs where it might still be open
  • If locked by your user close all tabs/sessions where that object could be open, sign out/in, and retry
  • If it looks stuck beyond a reasonable time especially if locked by a technical user or after a crash open an SAP incident with:
    • app name, object key
    • locking user shown in the message
    • timestamp and steps to reproduce

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002792742

3. Option

Public Cloud does deliver apps for certain application-level lock types but these are not a generic enqueue lock list like SM12

Examples:

  • FI-CA processing locks SAP explicitly points to Manage Processing Locks (F7450) to delete processing locks created by a job run using the FI-CA delete processing locks job template

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/cdccca8e03d74101a0135863bc522b49/8704c5536a51204be10000000a174cb4.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F7450')/S35

  • Clearing/posting/payment lock analytics exist as dedicated analytical apps for those business scenarios for example Analyze Clearing Locks app

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1653A')/S35

So there isn’t one universal lock entries Fiori app there are several domain apps depending on the business object/process

Summary:

In Public Cloud there is no SM12-equivalent that lets customers centrally display and force-delete ABAP enqueue lock entries the way you can in on-prem/private cloud. That’s intentional basis-level lock administration is restricted in Public Cloud to avoid data inconsistencies and to keep the tenant clean core

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: How AI-Assisted Process Analyzer Lets Any Business User Master Process Intelligence
entry.content:
The plan is to replace the actual Auto mapping that you can find on the dashboard by the AI-assisted one after the Beta testing. 

 AI Auto Mapping leverages large language models (LLMs) to enhance traditional auto mapping techniques, offering a more robust and reliable solution, particularly when dealing with higher fuzziness levels in names being compared.

This feature supports multiple language and also better deals with special cases, such as abbreviations effectively thanks to its AI-driven approach The motivation for this advanced mapping capability is to leverage it when dealing with generation of process atoms, which involves synthesizing atoms from various sources such as BPMNs, event logs, and unstructured data.

Thanks to @Roman Duris and @Robin Roceck for helping to give this answer.

entry.title: Re: CONVERT_KEY_NOT_MAPPED issue in I_SALESORDERTP BDEF
entry.content:
You need to fill ls_so_temp_key with the key before calling to CONVERT KEY.

Try with this:

MODIFY ENTITIES OF i_salesordertp
  ENTITY salesorder
  CREATE FIELDS ( salesordertype salesorganization distributionchannel organizationdivision soldtoparty )
  WITH VALUE #( ( %cid = 'cid1'
                  %data = VALUE #(
                    salesordertype = iv_sales_ordertype "'YSV'
                    salesorganization = iv_sales_organization "'5PUS'
                    distributionchannel = iv_distributionchannel "'10'
                    organizationdivision = iv_organizationdivision "'P1'
                    soldtoparty = iv_soldtoparty "'0000151520'
                  ) ) )
  CREATE BY \_item AUTO FILL CID
  FIELDS ( product
           requestedquantity
* plant
         )
  WITH VALUE #( ( %cid_ref = 'cid1'
                  %target = VALUE #( FOR ls_items IN lt_items (
                    product = ls_items-product
                    requestedquantity = ls_items-requestedquantity
* plant = '8359'
                  ) ) ) )
  MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped)
  FAILED DATA(ls_failed)
  REPORTED DATA(ls_reported_modify).

DATA: ls_so_temp_key TYPE STRUCTURE FOR KEY OF i_salesordertp.

COMMIT ENTITIES BEGIN
  RESPONSE OF i_salesordertp
  FAILED DATA(ls_save_failed)
  REPORTED DATA(ls_save_reported).

ls_so_temp_key-%cid = 'cid1'.
CONVERT KEY OF i_salesordertp FROM ls_so_temp_key TO DATA(ls_so_final_key).

COMMIT ENTITIES END.
